title: Islander 36
text:
The Islander 36, sometimes referred to as the I36, is an American <a href="sailboat">sailboat</a> that was designed by <a href="Alan%20Gurney">Alan Gurney</a> as a <a href="Cruising%20%28maritime%29">cruiser</a> and first built in 1971.
Production.
The design was built by <a href="Islander%20Yachts">Islander Yachts</a>/<a href="Tradewind%20Yachts">Tradewind Yachts</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> from 1971 until 1986 with 770 boats completed, but it is now out of production.
The molds were purchased by <a href="Newport%20Offshore%20Yachts">Newport Offshore Yachts</a> in 1986 but it is not known if any further boats were built.
Design.
The Islander 36 is a recreational <a href="keelboat">keelboat</a>, built predominantly of <a href="fiberglass">fiberglass</a>, with wood trim. It has a <a href="masthead%20sloop">masthead sloop</a> rig; a <a href="raked%20stem">raked stem</a>; a raised counter, <a href="reverse%20transom">reverse transom</a>; a <a href="skeg">skeg</a>-mounted <a href="rudder">rudder</a> controlled by a <a href="Ship%27s%20wheel">wheel</a> and a fixed fin <a href="keel">keel</a>. The fin keel model displaces and carries of lead ballast, while the shoal draft keel model displaces and carries of lead ballast.
The boat has a draft of with the standard keel and with the optional shoal draft keel.
A tall mast was also available for sailing in areas with lighter winds.
The boat was fitted with a large variety of <a href="inboard%20engine">inboard engine</a>s for docking and maneuvering, including the <a href="Universal%20Atomic%204">Universal Atomic 4</a> and the <a href="Palmer%20P-60">Palmer P-60</a> <a href="gasoline%20engine">gasoline engine</a>s, the British <a href="Perkins%20Engines">Perkins Engines</a> 4-108, <a href="Westerbeke%20L-25">Westerbeke L-25</a>, Pathfinder and Japanese <a href="Yanmar">Yanmar</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s. The fuel tank holds and the fresh water tank has a capacity of .
The design has sleeping accommodation for six people, with a double "V"-berth in the bow cabin and two straight settees in the main cabin that can be converted to doubles. The <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a> is located on the starboard side just forward of the <a href="companionway">companionway</a> ladder and is equipped with a three-burner stove and a double sink. A navigation station is opposite the galley, on the port side. The <a href="Head%20%28watercraft%29">head</a> is located just aft of the bow cabin on the port side.
Operational history.
The boat is supported by an active class club that organizes racing events, the "Islander 36 Association".
In a 2010 review in "Talk of The Dock", stated, "the Islander 36 (I36) is a true classic ... and they’re great boats that will go the distance or race quite impressively"
